verses.text: Earnest and worthy of respect as they are, I must therefore prefer a class of writers who breathe the spirit of the ante-Nicene Fathers as better elucidating the primitive epoch and its principles, alike in doctrine and worship.

verses.text: More elaborately, a recent writer of great erudition has expounded the same historic fact, and given us the pivot of Hebrew history on which turns the whole system of that "goodly fellowship of prophets" who heralded the Sun of righteousness as successive constellations rise before the day.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:29
verses.text: The learned Dean Payne-Smith, more minutely than Hippolytus, identifies Samuel, the master of David, as the great instrument of God in shaping the institutions of Moses to be a prelude to the Advent; in other words, transforming a local and tribal religion into that of Catholicity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:30
verses.text: The value of the Dean's condensed and luminous elaboration of this cardinal truth can hardly be overstated.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:31
verses.text: But, to go behind even the Dean's stand-point, we shall better comprehend the era of which, under God, Samuel was the author, by noting the immense importance of that specific Mosaic ordinance which not only made it possible, but which proves that an all-wise prolepsis governed the whole law of Moses.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:32
verses.text: We generally conceive of the Mosaic system as one of unlimited hecatombs and burnt-offerings.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:33
verses.text: On the contrary, it was a system restricting and limiting the unsystematized primeval institution of sacrifice, which had done its work by passing into the universal religions and rituals of Gentilism.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:34
verses.text: When the seminal idea of expiation, atonement, and the blood of innocence as a propitiation for guilt, was communicated to all the families of the earth, the Mosaic institutions limited sacrifices for the faithful, and localized them with marvellous significance.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:35
verses.text: Previously the faithful everywhere had imitated the sacrifices of their fathers, Noah and Abraham, who reared their altars everywhere, as Job also did,—wherever they dwelt or sojourned.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:36
verses.text: Now mark the first step towards a more spiritual worship, based, nevertheless, on the fundamental principle of sacrifice.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:44
verses.text: It was the office of Samuel to take the Mosaic ordinances just there, and to shape them for the advent of the Lamb of God, for His sacrifice upon Calvary, and for the setting-up of His universal kingdom.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:45
verses.text: The Institutions of Samuel, therefore, were in essence institutions for the Gospel-day, and they were completed by the anointing of David as king, and by his prophetic mission to provide the Psalter (of which more, by and by); then the Ark came out of curtains, and the Lord chose and appointed the place of which Moses had spoken,—none other than the spot where Abraham had rehearsed in type the Sacrifice and Resurrection of Christ, according as it was written: "Jehovah-Jireh…in the mount of the Lord it shall be seen".

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:46
verses.text: Thus, all sacrifice acceptable to God was shown to have reference to the Paschal Lamb, who on that mount of the Lord should be sacrificed, and rise again, as was accomplished in a figure aforetime.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:47
verses.text: And next, the Psalmist commemorates the putting away of the migratory Tabernacle, and the rest of the Ark of the Covenant in the place designed for the grand accomplishment of redemption ("the sure mercies of David"), as follows:—  "He refused the tabernacle of Joseph, and chose not the tribe of Ephraim: but chose the tribe of Judah, the Mount Zion which He loved.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:48
verses.text: And He built His sanctuary like high palaces, like the earth which He hath established for ever".

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:49
verses.text: Thus, localized sacrifice was made to designate the spot where the one propitiatory sacrifice should be offered, "for the sins of the whole world;" and that spot in turn interpreted the great canon of redemption,—  "Without shedding of blood is no remission:"  and all this, being accomplished in the Messiah, passed away for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:191
verses.text: To the Missa Catechumenorum, or that part of the service which preceded the prayers peculiar to communicants only, not only believers, but Gentiles, were admitted, in the hope that some might possibly become converts to the faith.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:192
verses.text: After the Psalms and Lessons with which the service commenced, as on ordinary occasions, a section from the Acts of the Apostles or the Epistles was read; after which the deacon or presbyter read the Gospel.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:193
verses.text: Then followed an exhortation from one or more of the presbyters; and the bishop or president delivered a Homily or Sermon, explanatory, it should seem, of the Scripture which had been read, and exciting the people to an imitation of the virtues therein exemplified.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 1:194
verses.text: When the preacher had concluded his discourse with a doxology in praise of the Holy Trinity, a deacon made proclamation for all infidels and non-communicants to withdraw; then came the dismissal of the several classes of catechumens, energumens, competents, and penitents, after the prayers for each respectively, as on ordinary days; and the Missa fidelium commenced.

verses.text: The Divine Liturgy of James the Holy Apostle and Brother of the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:2
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:3
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:4
verses.text: I O Sovereign Lord our God, contemn me not, defiled with a multitude of sins: for, behold, I have come to this Thy divine and heavenly mystery, not as being worthy; but looking only to Thy goodness, I direct my voice to Thee: God be merciful to me, a sinner; I have sinned against Heaven, and before Thee, and am unworthy to come into the presence of this Thy holy and spiritual table, upon which Thy only-begotten Son, and our Lord Jesus Christ, is mystically set forth as a sacrifice for me, a sinner, and stained with every spot.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:5
verses.text: Wherefore I present to Thee this supplication and thanksgiving, that Thy Spirit the Comforter may be sent down upon me, strengthening and fitting me for this service; and count me worthy to make known without condemnation the word, delivered from Thee by me to the people, in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom Thou art blessed, together with Thy all-holy, and good, and quickening, and consubstantial Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:6
verses.text: Prayer of the standing beside the altar.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:7
verses.text: II Glory to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit, the triune light of the Godhead, which is unity subsisting in trinity, divided, yet indivisible: for the Trinity is the one God Almighty, whose glory the heavens declare, and the earth His dominion, and the sea His might, and every sentient and intellectual creature at all times proclaims His majesty: for all glory becomes Him, and honour and might, greatness and magnificence, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:8
verses.text: Prayer of the incense at the beginning.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:9
verses.text: III Sovereign Lord Jesus Christ, O Word of God, who didst freely offer Thyself a blameless sacrifice upon the cross to God even the Father, the coal of double nature, that didst touch the lips of the prophet with the tongs, and didst take away his sins, touch also the hearts of us sinners, and purify us from every stain, and present us holy beside Thy holy altar, that we may offer Thee a sacrifice of praise: and accept from us, Thy unprofitable servants, this incense as an odour of a sweet smell, and make fragrant the evil odour of our soul and body, and purify us with the sanctifying power of Thy all-holy Spirit: for Thou alone art holy, who sanctifiest, and art communicated to the faithful; and glory becomes Thee, with Thy eternal Father, and Thy all-holy, and good, and quickening Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:10
verses.text: Prayer of the commencement.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:11
verses.text: IV O beneficent King eternal, and Creator of the universe, receive Thy Church, coming unto Thee through Thy Christ: fulfil to each what is profitable; lead all to perfection, and make us perfectly worthy of the grace of Thy sanctification, gathering us together within Thy holy Church, which Thou hast purchased by the precious blood of Thy only-begotten Son, and our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, with whom Thou art blessed and glorified, together with Thy all-holy, and good, and quickening Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:12
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:13
verses.text: V Let us again pray to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:14
verses.text: The Priest, prayer of the incense at the entrance of the congregation.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:15
verses.text: God, who didst accept the gifts of Abel, the sacrifice of Noah and of Abram, the incense of Aaron and of Zacharias, accept also from the hand of us sinners this incense for an odour of a sweet smell, and for remission of our sins, and those of all Thy people; for blessed art Thou, and glory becomes Thee, the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit, now and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:16
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:17
verses.text: Sir, pronounce the blessing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:18
verses.text: The Priest prays.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:19
verses.text: Our Lord and God, Jesus Christ, who through exceeding goodness and love not to be restrained wast crucified, and didst not refuse to be pierced by the spear and nails; who didst provide this mysterious and awful service as an everlasting memorial for us perpetually: bless Thy ministry in Christ the God, and bless our entrance, and fully complete the presentation of this our service by Thy unutterable compassion, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:20
verses.text: The responsive prayer from the Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:21
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:22
verses.text: The Lord bless us, and make us worthy seraphically to offer gifts, and to sing the oft-sung hymn of the divine Trisagion, by the fulness and exceeding abundance of all the perfection of holiness, now and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:23
verses.text: Then the Deacon begins to sing in the entrance.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:24
verses.text: Thou who art the only-begotten Son and Word of God, immortal; who didst submit for our salvation to become flesh of the holy God-mother, and ever-virgin Mary; who didst immutably become man and wast crucified, O Christ our God, and didst by Thy death tread death underfoot; who art one of the Holy Trinity glorified together with the Father and the Holy Spirit, save us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:25
verses.text: The Priest says this prayer from the gates to the altar.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:26
verses.text: VII God Almighty, Lord great in glory, who hast given to us an entrance into the Holy of Holies, through the sojourning among men of Thy only-begotten Son, our Lord, and God, and Saviour Jesus Christ, we supplicate and invoke Thy goodness, since we are fearful and trembling when about to stand at Thy holy altar; send forth upon us, O God, Thy good grace, and sanctify our souls, and bodies, and spirits, and turn our thoughts to piety, in order that with a pure conscience we may bring unto Thee gifts, offerings, and fruits for the remission of our transgressions, and for the propitiation of all Thy people, by the grace and mercies and loving-kindness of Thy only-begotten Son, with whom Thou art blessed to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:27
verses.text: After the approach to the altar, the Priest says:—  VIII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:28
verses.text: Peace be to all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:29
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:30
verses.text: And to thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:31
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:32
verses.text: The Lord bless us all, and sanctify us for the entrance and celebration of the divine and pure mysteries, giving rest to the blessed souls among the good and just, by His grace and loving-kindness, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:33
verses.text: Then the Deacon says the bidding prayer.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:34
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:35
verses.text: In peace let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:36
verses.text: For the peace that is from above, and for God's love to man, and for the salvation of our souls, let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:37
verses.text: For the peace of the whole world, for the unity of all the holy churches of God, let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:38
verses.text: For the remission of our sins, and forgiveness of our transgressions, and for our deliverance from all tribulation, wrath, danger, and distress, and from the uprising of our enemies, let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:39
verses.text: Then the Singers sing the Trisagion Hymn.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:40
verses.text: Holy God, holy mighty, holy immortal, have mercy upon us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:41
verses.text: Then the Priest prays, bowing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:42
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:43
verses.text: O compassionate and merciful, long-suffering, and very gracious and true God, look from Thy prepared dwelling-place, and hear us Thy suppliants, and deliver us from every temptation of the devil and of man; withhold not Thy aid from us, nor bring on us chastisements too heavy for our strength: for we are unable to overcome what is opposed to us; but Thou art able, Lord, to save us from everything that is against us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:44
verses.text: Save us, O God, from the difficulties of this world, according to Thy goodness, in order that, having drawn nigh with a pure conscience to Thy holy altar, we may send up to Thee without condemnation the blessed hymn Trisagion, together with the heavenly powers, and that, having performed the service, well pleasing to Thee and divine, we may be counted worthy of eternal life.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:45
verses.text: (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:46
verses.text: )  Because Thou art holy, Lord our God, and dwellest and abidest in holy places, we send up the praise and the hymn Trisagion to Thee, the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:47
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:48
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:49
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.text: XI.

verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:56
verses.text: Then there are read in order the holy oracles of the Old Testament, and of the prophets; and the incarnation of the Son of God is set forth, and His sufferings and resurrection from the dead, His ascension into heaven, and His second appearing with glory; and this takes place daily in the holy and divine service.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:57
verses.text: After the reading and instruction the Deacon says:—  XII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:58
verses.text: Let us all say, Lord, be merciful.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:59
verses.text: Lord Almighty, the God of our fathers;  We beseech Thee, hear us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:60
verses.text: For the peace which is from above, and for the salvation of our souls;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:61
verses.text: For the peace of the whole world, and the unity of all the holy churches of God;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:62
verses.text: For the salvation and help of all the Christ-loving people;  We beseech Thee, hear us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:63
verses.text: For our deliverance from all tribulation, wrath, danger, distress, from captivity, bitter death, and from our iniquities;  We beseech Thee, hear us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:64
verses.text: For the people standing round, and waiting for the rich and plenteous mercy that is from Thee;  We beseech Thee, be merciful and gracious.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:65
verses.text: Save Thy people, O Lord, and bless Thine inheritance.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:66
verses.text: Visit Thy world in mercy and compassion.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:67
verses.text: Exalt the horn of Christians by the power of the precious and quickening cross.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:68
verses.text: We beseech Thee, most merciful Lord, hear us praying to Thee, and have mercy upon us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:69
verses.text: The People (thrice).

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:70
verses.text: Lord, have mercy upon us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:71
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:72
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:73
verses.text: For the remission of our sins, and forgiveness of our transgressions, and for our deliverance from all tribulation, wrath, danger, and distress, let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:74
verses.text: Let us all entreat from the Lord, that we may pass the whole day, perfect, holy, peaceful, and without sin.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:75
verses.text: Let us entreat from the Lord a messenger of peace, a faithful guide, a guardian of our souls and bodies.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:76
verses.text: Let us entreat from the Lord forgiveness and remission of our sins and transgressions.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:77
verses.text: Let us entreat from the Lord the things which are good and proper for our souls, and peace for the world.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:78
verses.text: Let us entreat from the Lord, that we may spend the remaining period of our life in peace and health.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:79
verses.text: Let us entreat that the close of our lives may be Christian, without pain and without shame, and a good plea at the dread and awful judgment-seat of Christ.

verses.text: The Priest.

verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:82
verses.text: For Thou art the gospel and the light, Saviour and keeper of our souls and bodies, God, and Thy only-begotten Son, and Thy all-holy Spirit, now and ever.

verses.text: And to Thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:95
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:96
verses.text: Let us bow our heads to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:97
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:98
verses.text: To Thee, Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:99
verses.text: The Priest prays, saying:—  O Sovereign giver of life, and provider of good things, who didst give to mankind the blessed hope of eternal life, our Lord Jesus Christ, count us worthy in holiness, and perfect this Thy divine service to the enjoyment of future blessedness.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:100
verses.text: (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:101
verses.text: )  So that, guarded by Thy power at all times, and led into the light of truth, we may send up the praise and the thanksgiving to Thee, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, now and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:102
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:103
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:104
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:105
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:106
verses.text: Let none remain of the catechumens, none of the unbaptized, none of those who are unable to join with us in prayer.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:107
verses.text: Look at one another.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:108
verses.text: The door.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:109
verses.text: All erect: let us again pray to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:110
verses.text: II  The Priest says the prayer of incense.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:111
verses.text: Sovereign Almighty, King of Glory, who knowest all things before their creation, manifest Thyself to us calling upon Thee at this holy hour, and redeem us from the shame of our transgressions; cleanse our mind and our thoughts from impure desires, from worldly deceit, from all influence of the devil; and accept from the hands of us sinners this incense, as Thou didst accept the offering of Abel, and Noah, and Aaron, and Samuel, and of all Thy saints, guarding us from everything evil, and preserving us for continually pleasing, and worshipping, and glorifying Thee, the Father, and Thy only-begotten Son, and Thy all-holy Spirit, now and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:112
verses.text: And the Readers begin the Cherubic Hymn.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:113
verses.text: Let all mortal flesh be silent, and stand with fear and trembling, and meditate nothing earthly within itself:—  For the King of kings and Lord of lords, Christ our God, comes forward to be sacrificed, and to be given for food to the faithful; and the bands of angels go before Him with every power and dominion, the many-eyed cherubim, and the six-winged seraphim, covering their faces, and crying aloud the hymn, Alleluia, Alleluia, Alleluia.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:114
verses.text: The Priest, bringing in the holy gifts, says this prayer:—  XVII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:115
verses.text: O God, our God, who didst send forth the heavenly bread, the food of the whole world, our Lord Jesus Christ, to be a Saviour, and Redeemer, and Benefactor, blessing and sanctifying us, do Thou Thyself bless this offering, and graciously receive it to Thy altar above the skies:  Remember in Thy goodness and love those who have brought it, and those for whom they have brought it, and preserve us without condemnation in the service of Thy divine mysteries: for hollowed and glorified is Thy all-honoured and great name, Father, and Son, and Holy Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:116
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:117
verses.text: Peace be to all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:118
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:119
verses.text: Sir, pronounce the blessing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:120
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:121
verses.text: Blessed be God, who blesseth and sanctifieth us all at the presentation of the divine and pure mysteries, and giveth rest to the blessed souls among the holy and just, now and always, and to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:122
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:123
verses.text: XVIII Let us attend in wisdom.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:124
verses.text: The Priest begins.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:125
verses.text: I believe in one God, Father Almighty, Maker of heaven and earth, and in one Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of God: and the rest of the Creed.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:126
verses.text: Then he prays, bowing his neck.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:127
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:128
verses.text: God and Sovereign of all, make us, who are unworthy, worthy of this hour, lover of mankind; that being pure from all deceit and all hypocrisy, we may be united with one another by the bond of peace and love, being confirmed by the sanctification of Thy divine knowledge through Thine only-begotten Son, our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, with whom Thou art blessed, together with Thy all-holy, and good, and quickening Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:129
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:130
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:131
verses.text: Let us stand well, let us stand reverently, let us stand in the fear of God, and with compunction of heart.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:132
verses.text: In peace let us pray to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:133
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:134
verses.text: For God of peace, mercy, love, compassion, and loving-kindness art Thou, and Thine only-begotten Son, and Thine all-holy Spirit, now and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:135
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:136
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:137
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:138
verses.text: Peace be to all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:139
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:140
verses.text: And to thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:141
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:142
verses.text: Let us salute one another with an holy kiss.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:143
verses.text: Let us bow our heads to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:144
verses.text: The Priest bows, saying this prayer:—  XXI.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:145
verses.text: Only Lord and merciful God, on those who are bowing their necks before Thy holy altar, and seeking the spiritual gifts that come from Thee, send forth Thy good grace; and bless us all with every spiritual blessing, that cannot be taken from us, Thou, who dwellest on high, and hast regard unto things that are lowly.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:146
verses.text: (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:147
verses.text: )  For worthy of praise and worship and most glorious is Thy all-holy name, Father and Son and Holy Spirit, now and always, and to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:148
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:149
verses.text: Sir, pronounce the blessing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:150
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:151
verses.text: The Lord will bless us, and minister with us all by His grace and loving-kindness.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:152
verses.text: And again.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:153
verses.text: The Lord will bless us, and make us worthy to stand at His holy altar, at all times, now and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:154
verses.text: And again.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:155
verses.text: Blessed be God, who blesseth and sanctifieth us all in our attendance upon, and service of, His pure mysteries, now and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:156
verses.text: The Deacon makes the Universal Litany.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:157
verses.text: XXII In peace let us pray to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:158
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:159
verses.text: O Lord, have mercy.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:160
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:161
verses.text: Save us, have mercy upon us, pity and keep us, O God, by Thy grace.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:162
verses.text: For the peace that is from above, and the loving-kindness of God, and the salvation of our souls;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:163
verses.text: For the peace of the whole world, and the unity of all the holy churches of God;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:164
verses.text: For those who bear fruit, and labour honourably in the holy churches of God; for those who remember the poor, the widows and the orphans, the strangers and needy ones; and for those who have requested us to mention them in our prayers;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:165
verses.text: For those who are in old age and infirmity, for the sick and suffering, and those who are troubled by unclean spirits, for their speedy cure from God and their salvation;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:166
verses.text: For those who are passing their days in virginity, and celibacy, and discipline, and for those in holy matrimony; and for the holy fathers and brethren agonizing in mountains, and dens, and caves of the earth;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:167
verses.text: For Christians sailing, travelling, living among strangers, and for our brethren in captivity, in exile, in prison, and in bitter slavery, their peaceful return;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:168
verses.text: For the remission of our sins, and forgiveness of our transgressions, and for our deliverance from all tribulation, wrath, danger, and constraint, and uprising against us of enemies;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:169
verses.text: For favourable weather, peaceful showers, beneficent dews, abundance of fruits, the perfect close of a good season, and for the crown of the year;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:170
verses.text: For our fathers and brethren present, and praying with us in this holy hour, and at every season, their zeal, labour, and earnestness;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:171
verses.text: For every Christian soul in tribulation and distress, and needing the mercy and succour of God; for the return of the erring, the health of the sick, the deliverance of the captives, the rest of the fathers and brethren that have fallen asleep aforetime;  Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:172
verses.text: For the hearing and acceptance of our prayer before God, and the sending down on us His rich mercies and compassion.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:173
verses.text: Let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:174
verses.text: And for the offered, precious, heavenly, unutterable, pure, glorious, dread, awful, divine gifts, and the salvation of the priest who stands by and offers them;  Let us offer supplication to God the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:175
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:176
verses.text: O Lord, have mercy.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:177
verses.text: (Thrice.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:178
verses.text: )  Then the Priest makes the sign of the cross on the gifts, and, standing, speaks separately thus:—  XXIII Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good-will among men, etc.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:179
verses.text: (Thrice.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:180
verses.text: )  Lord, Thou wilt open my lips, and my mouth shall show forth Thy praise.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:181
verses.text: (Thrice.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:182
verses.text: )  Let my mouth be filled with Thy praise, O Lord, that I may tell of Thy glory, of Thy majesty, all the day.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:183
verses.text: (Thrice.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:184
verses.text: )  Of the Father, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:185
verses.text: And of the Son, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:186
verses.text: And of the Holy Spirit, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:187
verses.text: Now and always, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:188
verses.text: And bowing to this side and to that, he says:  XXIV.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:189
verses.text: Magnify the Lord with me, and let us exalt His name together.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:190
verses.text: And they answer, bowing:—  The Holy Ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:191
verses.text: Then the Priest, at great length:—  O Sovereign Lord, who hast visited us in compassion and mercies, and hast freely given to us, Thy humble and sinful and unworthy servants, boldness to stand at Thy holy altar, and to offer to Thee this dread and bloodless sacrifice for our sins, and for the errors of the people, look upon me Thy unprofitable servant, and blot out my transgressions for Thy compassion's sake; and purify my lips and heart from all pollution of flesh and spirit; and remove from me every shameful and foolish thought, and fit me by the power of Thy all-holy Spirit for this service; and receive me graciously by Thy goodness as I draw nigh to Thy altar.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:192
verses.text: And be pleased, O Lord, that these gifts brought by our hands may be acceptable, stooping to my weakness; and cast me not away from Thy presence, and abhor not my unworthiness; but pity me according to Thy great mercy, and according to the multitude of Thy mercies pass by my transgressions, that, having come before Thy glory without condemnation, I may be counted worthy of the protection of Thy only-begotten Son, and of the illumination of Thy all-holy Spirit, that I may not be as a slave of sin cast out, but as Thy servant may find grace and mercy and forgiveness of sins before Thee, both in the world that now is and in that which is to come.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:193
verses.text: I beseech Thee, Almighty Sovereign, all-powerful Lord, hear my prayer; for Thou art He who workest all in all, and we all seek in all things the help and succour that come from Thee and Thy only-begotten Son, and the good and quickening and consubstantial Spirit, now and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:194
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:195
verses.text: O God, who through Thy great and unspeakable love didst send forth Thy only-begotten Son into the world, in order that He might turn back the lost sheep, turn not away us sinners, laying hold of Thee by this dread and bloodless sacrifice; for we trust not in our own righteousness, but in Thy good mercy, by which Thou purchasest our race.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:196
verses.text: We entreat and beseech Thy goodness that it may not be for condemnation to Thy people that this mystery for salvation has been administered by us, but for remission of sins, for renewal of souls and bodies, for the well-pleasing of Thee, God and Father, in the mercy and love of Thy only-begotten Son, with whom Thou art blessed, together with Thy all-holy and good and quickening Spirit, now and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:197
verses.text: XXVI.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:198
verses.text: O Lord God, who didst create us, and bring us into life, who hast shown to us ways to salvation, who hast granted to us a revelation of heavenly mysteries, and hast appointed us to this ministry in the power of Thy all-holy Spirit, grant, O Sovereign, that we may become servants of Thy new testament, ministers of Thy pure mysteries, and receive us as we draw near to Thy holy altar, according to the greatness of Thy mercy, that we may become worthy of offering to Thee gifts and sacrifices for our transgressions and for those of the people; and grant to us, O Lord, with all fear and a pure conscience to offer to Thee this spiritual and bloodless sacrifice, and graciously receiving it unto Thy holy and spiritual altar above the skies for an odour of a sweet spiritual smell, send down in answer on us the grace of Thy all-holy Spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:199
verses.text: And, O God, look upon us, and have regard to this our reasonable service, and accept it, as Thou didst accept the gifts of Abel, the sacrifices of Noah, the priestly offices of Moses and Aaron, the peace-offerings of Samuel, the repentance of David, the incense of Zacharias.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:200
verses.text: As Thou didst accept from the hand of Thy apostles this true service, so accept also in Thy goodness from the hands of us sinners these offered gifts; and grant that our offering may be acceptable, sanctified by the Holy Spirit, as a propitiation for our transgressions and the errors of the people; and for the rest of the souls that have fallen asleep aforetime; that we also, Thy humble, sinful, and unworthy servants, being counted worthy without guile to serve Thy holy altar, may receive the reward of faithful and wise stewards, and may find grace and mercy in the terrible day of Thy just and good retribution.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:201
verses.text: Prayer of the veil.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:202
verses.text: XXVII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:203
verses.text: We thank Thee, O Lord our God, that Thou hast given us boldness for the entrance of Thy holy places, which Thou hast renewed to us as a new and living way through the veil of the flesh of Thy Christ.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:204
verses.text: We therefore, being counted worthy to enter into the place of the tabernacle of Thy glory, and to be within the veil, and to behold the Holy of Holies, cast ourselves down before Thy goodness:  Lord, have mercy on us: since we are full of fear and trembling, when about to stand at Thy holy altar, and to offer this dread and bloodless sacrifice for our own sins and for the errors of the people: send forth, O God, Thy good grace, and sanctify our souls, and bodies, and spirits; and turn our thoughts to holiness, that with a pure conscience we may bring to Thee a peace-offering, the sacrifice of praise:  (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:205
verses.text: )  By the mercy and loving-kindness of Thy only-begotten Son, with whom Thou art blessed, together with Thy all-holy, and good, and quickening Spirit, now and always:  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:206
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:207
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:208
verses.text: Peace be to all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:209
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:210
verses.text: Let us stand reverently, let us stand in the fear of God, and with contrition: let us attend to the holy communion service, to offer peace to God.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:211
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:212
verses.text: The offering of peace, the sacrifice of praise.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:213
verses.text: The Priest A veil is now withdrawn from the oblation of bread and wine.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:214
verses.text: And, uncovering the veils that darkly invest in symbol this sacred ceremonial, do Thou reveal it clearly to us: fill our intellectual vision with absolute light, and having purified our poverty from every pollution of flesh and spirit, make it worthy of this dread and awful approach: for Thou art an all-merciful and gracious God, and we send up the praise and the thanksgiving to Thee, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, now, and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:215
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:216
verses.text: The Anaphora.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:217
verses.text: Then he says aloud:—  XXVIII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:218
verses.text: The love of the Lord and Father, the grace of the Lord and Son, and the fellowship and the gift of the Holy Spirit, be with us all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:219
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:220
verses.text: And with thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:221
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:222
verses.text: Let us lift up our minds and our hearts.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:223
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:224
verses.text: It is becoming and right.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:225
verses.text: Then the Priest prays.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:226
verses.text: Verily it is becoming and right, proper and due to praise Thee, to sing of Thee, to bless Thee, to worship Thee, to glorify Thee, to give Thee thanks, Maker of every creature visible and invisible, the treasure of eternal good things, the fountain of life and immortality, God and Lord of all:  Whom the heavens of heavens praise, and all the host of them; the sun, and the moon, and all the choir of the stars; earth, sea, and all that is in them; Jerusalem, the heavenly assembly, and church of the first-born that are written in heaven; spirits of just men and of prophets; souls of martyrs and of apostles; angels, archangels, thrones, dominions, principalities, and authorities, and dread powers; and the many-eyed cherubim, and the six-winged seraphim, which cover their faces with two wings, their feet with two, and with two they fly, crying one to another with unresting lips, with unceasing praises:  (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:227
verses.text: )  With loud voice singing the victorious hymn of Thy majestic glory, crying aloud, praising, shouting, and saying:—  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:228
verses.text: Holy, holy, holy, O Lord of Sabaoth, the heaven and the earth are full of Thy glory.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:229
verses.text: Hosanna in the highest; blessed is He that cometh in the name of the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:230
verses.text: Hosanna in the highest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:231
verses.text: The Priest, making the sign of the cross on the gifts, says:—  XXIX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:232
verses.text: Holy art Thou, King of eternity, and Lord and giver of all holiness; holy also Thy only-begotten Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom Thou hast made all things; holy also Thy Holy Spirit, which searches all things, even Thy deep things, O God: holy art Thou, almighty, all-powerful, good, dread, merciful, most compassionate to Thy creatures; who didst make man from earth after Thine own image and likeness; who didst give him the joy of paradise; and when he transgressed Thy commandment, and fell away, didst not disregard nor desert him, O Good One, but didst chasten him as at merciful father, call him by the law, instruct him by the prophets; and afterwards didst send forth Thine only-begotten Son Himself, our Lord Jesus Christ, into the world, that He by His coming might renew and restore Thy image;  Who, having descended from heaven, and become flesh of the Holy Spirit and Virgin Godmother Mary, and having sojourned among men, fulfilled the dispensation for the salvation of our race; and being about to endure His voluntary and life-giving death by the cross, He the sinless for us the sinners, in the night in which He was betrayed, nay, rather delivered Himself up for the life and salvation of the world,  Then the Priest holds the bread in his hand, and says:—  XXX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:233
verses.text: Having taken the bread in His holy and pure and blameless and immortal hands, lifting up His eyes to heaven, and showing it to Thee, His God and Father, He gave thanks, and hallowed, and brake, and gave it to us, His disciples and apostles, saying:—  The Deacons say:  For the remission of sins and life everlasting.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:234
verses.text: Then he says aloud:—  Take, eat: this is my body, broken for you, and given for remission of sins.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:235
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:236
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:237
verses.text: Then he takes the cup, and says:—  In like manner, after supper, He took the cup, and having mixed wine and water, lifting up His eyes to heaven, and presenting it to Thee, His God and Father, He gave thanks, and hollowed and blessed it, and filled it with the Holy Spirit, and gave it to us His disciples, saying, Drink ye all of it; this is my blood of the new testament shed for you and many, and distributed for the remission of sins.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:238
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:239
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:240
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:241
verses.text: This do in remembrance of me; for as often as ye eat this bread, and drink this cup, ye do show forth the Lord's death, and confess His resurrection, till He come.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:242
verses.text: The Deacons say:—  We believe and confess:  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:243
verses.text: We show forth Thy death, O Lord, and confess Thy resurrection.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:244
verses.text: The Priest (Oblation).

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:245
verses.text: XXXI.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:246
verses.text: Remembering, therefore, His life-giving sufferings, His saving cross, His death and His burial, and resurrection from the dead on the third day, and His ascension into heaven, and sitting at the right hand of Thee, our God and Father, and His second glorious and awful appearing, when He shall come with glory to judge the quick and the dead, and render to every one according to His works; even we, sinful men, offer unto Thee, O Lord, this dread and bloodless sacrifice, praying that Thou wilt not deal with us after our sins, nor reward us according to our iniquities;  But that Thou, according to Thy mercy and Thy unspeakable loving-kindness, passing by and blotting out the handwriting against us Thy suppliants, wilt grant to us Thy heavenly and eternal gifts (which eye hath not seen, and ear hath not heard, and which have not entered into the heart of man) that thou hast prepared, O God, for those who love Thee; and reject not, O loving Lord, the people for my sake, or for my sin's sake:  Then he says, thrice:—  For Thy people and Thy Church supplicate Thee.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:247
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:248
verses.text: Have mercy on us, O Lord our God, Father Almighty.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:249
verses.text: Again the Priest says (Invocation):—  XXXII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:250
verses.text: Have mercy upon us, O God Almighty.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:251
verses.text: Have mercy upon us, O God our Saviour.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:252
verses.text: Have mercy upon us, O God, according to Thy great mercy, and send forth on us, and on these offered gifts, Thy all-holy Spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:253
verses.text: Then, bowing his neck, he says:—  The sovereign and quickening Spirit, that sits upon the throne with Thee, our God and Father, and with Thy only-begotten Son, reigning with Thee; the consubstantial and co-eternal; that spoke in the law and in the prophets, and in Thy New Testament; that descended in the form of a dove on our Lord Jesus Christ at the river Jordan, and abode on Him; that descended on Thy apostles in the form of tongues of fire in the upper room of the holy and glorious Zion on the day of Pentecost: this Thine all-holy Spirit, send down, O Lord, upon us, and upon these offered holy gifts;  And rising up, he says aloud:—  That coming, by His holy and good and glorious appearing, He may sanctify this bread, and make it the holy body of Thy Christ.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:254
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:255
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:256
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:257
verses.text: And this cup the precious blood of Thy Christ.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:258
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:259
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:260
verses.text: The Priest by himself standing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:261
verses.text: XXXIII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:262
verses.text: That they may be to all that partake of them for remission of sins, and for life everlasting, for the sanctification of souls and of bodies, for bearing the fruit of good works, for the stablishing of Thy Holy Catholic Church, which Thou hast founded on the Rock of Faith, that the gates of hell may not prevail against it; delivering it from all heresy and scandals, and from those who work iniquity, keeping it till the fulness of the time.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:263
verses.text: And having bowed, he says:—  XXXIV.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:264
verses.text: We present them to Thee also, O Lord, for the holy places, which Thou hast glorified by the divine appearing of Thy Christ, and by the visitation of Thy all-holy Spirit; especially for the glorious Zion, the mother of all the churches; and for Thy Holy, Catholic, and Apostolic Church throughout the world: even now, O Lord, bestow upon her the rich gifts of Thy all-holy Spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:265
verses.text: Remember also, O Lord, our holy fathers and brethren in it, and the bishops in all the world, who rightly divide the word of Thy truth.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:266
verses.text: Remember also, O Lord, every city and country, and those of the true faith dwelling in them, their peace and security.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:267
verses.text: Remember, O Lord, Christians sailing, travelling, sojourning in strange lands; our fathers and brethren, who are in bonds, prison, captivity, and exile; who are in mines, and under torture, and in bitter slavery.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:268
verses.text: Remember, O Lord, the sick and afflicted, and those troubled by unclean spirits, their speedy healing from Thee, O God, and their salvation.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:269
verses.text: Remember, O Lord, every Christian soul in affliction and distress, needing Thy mercy and succour, O God; and the return of the erring.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:270
verses.text: Remember, O Lord, our fathers and brethren, toiling hard, and ministering unto us, for Thy holy name's sake.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:271
verses.text: Remember all, O Lord, for good: have mercy on all, O Lord, be reconciled to us all: give peace to the multitudes of Thy people: put away scandals: bring wars to an end: make the uprising of heresies to cease: grant Thy peace and Thy love to us, O God our Saviour, the hope of all the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:272
verses.text: Remember, O Lord, favourable weather, peaceful showers, beneficent dews, abundance of fruits, and to crown the year with Thy goodness; for the eyes of all wait on Thee, and Thou givest their food in due season: thou openest Thy hand, and fillest every living thing with gladness.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:273
verses.text: Remember, O Lord, those who bear fruit, and labour honourably in the holy of Thy Church; and those who forget not the poor, the widows, the orphans, the strangers, and the needy; and all who have desired us to remember them in our prayers.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:274
verses.text: Moreover, O Lord, be pleased to remember those who have brought these offerings this day to Thy holy altar, and for what each one has brought them or with what mind, and those persons who have just now been mentioned to Thee.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:275
verses.text: Remember, O Lord, according to the multitude of Thy mercy and compassion, me also, Thy humble and unprofitable servant; and the deacons who surround Thy holy altar, and graciously give them a blameless life, keep their ministry undefiled, and purchase for them a good degree, that we may find mercy and grace, with all the saints that have been well pleasing to Thee since the world began, to generation and generation—grandsires, sires, patriarchs, prophets, apostles, martyrs, confessors, teachers, saints, and every just spirit made perfect in the faith of Thy Christ.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:276
verses.text: XXXV.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:277
verses.text: Hail, Mary, highly favoured: the Lord is with Thee; blessed art thou among women, and blessed the fruit of thy womb, for thou didst bear the Saviour of our souls.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:278
verses.text: The Deacons.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:279
verses.text: XXXVI.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:280
verses.text: Remember us, O Lord God.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:281
verses.text: The Priest, bowing, says:—  Remember, O Lord God, the spirits and all flesh, of whom we have made mention, and of whom we have not made mention, who are of the true faith, from righteous Abel unto this day: unto them do Thou give rest there in the land of the living, in Thy kingdom, in the joy of paradise, in the bosom of Abraham, and of Isaac, and of Jacob, our holy fathers; whence pain, and grief, and lamentation have fled: there the light of Thy countenance looks upon them, and enlightens them for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:282
verses.text: Make the end of our lives Christian, acceptable, blameless, and peaceful, O Lord, gathering us together, O Lord, under the feet of Thine elect, when Thou wilt, and as Thou wilt; only without shame and transgressions, through Thy only-begotten Son, our Lord and God and Saviour Jesus Christ: for He is the only sinless one who hath appeared on the earth.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:283
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:284
verses.text: And let us pray:—  For the peace and establishing of the whole world, and of the holy churches of God, and for the purposes for which each one made his offering, or according to the desire he has: and for the people standing round, and for all men, and all women:  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:285
verses.text: And for all men and all women.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:286
verses.text: (Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:287
verses.text: )  The Priest says aloud:—  Wherefore, both to them and to us, do Thou in Thy goodness and love:  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:288
verses.text: Forgive, remit, pardon, O God, our transgressions, voluntary and involuntary: in deed and in word: in knowledge and in ignorance: by night and by day: in thought and intent: in Thy goodness and love, forgive us them all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:289
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:290
verses.text: Through the grace and compassion and love of Thy only-begotten Son, with whom Thou art blessed and glorified, together with the all-holy, and good, and quickening Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:291
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:292
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:293
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:294
verses.text: XXXVII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:295
verses.text: Peace be to all:  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:296
verses.text: And to thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:297
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:298
verses.text: Again, and continually, in peace let us pray to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:299
verses.text: For the gifts to the Lord God presented and sanctified, precious, heavenly, unspeakable, pure, glorious, dread, awful, divine;  Let us pray.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:300
verses.text: That the Lord our God, having graciously received them to His altar that is holy and above the heavens, rational and spiritual, for the odour of a sweet spiritual savour, may send down in answer upon us the divine grace and the gift of the all-holy Spirit;  Let us pray.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:301
verses.text: Having prayed for the unity of the faith, and the communion of His all-holy and adorable Spirit;  Let us commend ourselves and one another, and our whole life, to Christ our God:  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:302
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:303
verses.text: The Priest prays.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:304
verses.text: XXXVIII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:305
verses.text: God and Father of our Lord and God and Saviour Jesus Christ, the glorious Lord, the blessed essence, the bounteous goodness, the God and Sovereign of all, who art blessed to all eternity, who sittest upon the cherubim, and art glorified by the seraphim, before whom stand thousand thousands and ten thousand times ten thousand hosts of angels and archangels: Thou hast accepted the gifts, offerings, and fruits brought unto Thee as an odour of a sweet spiritual smell, and hast been pleased to sanctify them, and make them perfect, O good One, by the grace of Thy Christ, and by the presence of Thy all-holy Spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:306
verses.text: Sanctify also, O Lord, our souls, and bodies, and spirits, and touch our understandings, and search our consciences, and cast out from us every evil imagination, every impure feeling, every base desire, every unbecoming thought, all envy, and vanity, and hypocrisy, all lying, all deceit, every worldly affection, all covetousness, all vainglory, all indifference, all vice, all passion, all anger, all malice, all blasphemy, every motion of the flesh and spirit that is not in accordance with Thy holy will:   (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:307
verses.text: )  And count us worthy, O loving Lord, with boldness, without condemnation, in a pure heart, with a contrite spirit, with unshamed face, with sanctified lips, to dare to call upon Thee, the holy God, Father in heaven, and to say,  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:308
verses.text: Our Father, which art in heaven: hollowed be Thy name; and so on to the doxology.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:309
verses.text: The Priest, bowing, says (the Embolism):—  And lead us not into temptation, Lord, Lord of Hosts, who knowest our frailty, but deliver us from the evil one and his works, and from all his malice and craftiness, for the sake of Thy holy name, which has been placed upon our humility:  (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:310
verses.text: )  For Thine is the kingdom, the power, and the glory, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, now and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:311
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:312
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:313
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:314
verses.text: XXXIX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:315
verses.text: Peace be to all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:316
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:317
verses.text: And to thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:318
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:319
verses.text: Let us bow our heads to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:320
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:321
verses.text: To Thee, O Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:322
verses.text: The Priest prays, speaking thus:—  To Thee, O Lord, we Thy servants have bowed our heads before Thy holy altar, waiting for the rich mercies that are from Thee.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:323
verses.text: Send forth upon us, O Lord, Thy plenteous grace and Thy blessing; and sanctify our souls, bodies, and spirits, that we may become worthy communicants and partakers of Thy holy mysteries, to the forgiveness of sins and life everlasting:  (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:324
verses.text: )  For adorable and glorified art Thou, our God, and Thy only-begotten Son, and Thy all-holy Spirit, now and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:325
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:326
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:327
verses.text: The Priest says aloud:—  And the grace and the mercies of the holy and consubstantial, and uncreated, and adorable Trinity, shall be with us all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:328
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:329
verses.text: And with thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:330
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:331
verses.text: In the fear of God, let us attend.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:332
verses.text: The Priest says secretly:—  O holy Lord, that abidest in holy places, sanctify us by the word of Thy grace, and by the visitation of Thy all-holy Spirit: for Thou, O Lord, hast said, Ye will be holy, for I am holy.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:333
verses.text: O Lord our God, incomprehensible Word of God, one in substance with the Father and the Holy Spirit, co-eternal and indivisible, accept the pure hymn, in Thy holy and bloodless sacrifices; with the cherubim, and seraphim, and from me, a sinful man, crying and saying:—  He takes up the gifts and saith aloud:—  XL.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:334
verses.text: The holy things unto holy.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:335
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:336
verses.text: One only is holy, one Lord Jesus Christ, to the glory of God the Father, to whom be glory to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:337
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:338
verses.text: XLI.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:339
verses.text: For the remission of our sins, and the propitiation of our souls, and for every soul in tribulation and distress, needing the mercy and succour of God, and for the return of the erring, the healing of the sick, the deliverance of the captives, the rest of our fathers and brethren who have fallen asleep aforetime;  Let us all say fervently, Lord, have mercy:  The People (twelve times).

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:340
verses.text: Lord, have mercy.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:341
verses.text: Then the Priest breaks the bread, and holds the half in his right hand, and the half in his left, and dips that in his right hand in the chalice, saying:—  The union of the all-holy body and precious blood of our Lord and God and Saviour, Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:342
verses.text: Then he makes the sign of the cross on that in his left hand: then with that which has been signed the other half: then forthwith he begins to divide, and before all to give to each chalice a single piece, saying:—  It has been made one, and sanctified, and perfected, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit, now and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:343
verses.text: And when he makes the sign of the cross on the bread, he says:—  Behold the Lamb of God, the Son of the Father, that taketh away the sin of the world, sacrificed for the life and salvation of the world.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:344
verses.text: And when he gives a single piece to each chalice he says:—  A holy portion of Christ, full of grace and truth, of the Father, and of the Holy Spirit, to whom be the glory and the power to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:345
verses.text: Then he begins to divide, and to say:—  XLII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:346
verses.text: The Lord is my Shepherd, I shall not want.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:347
verses.text: In green pastures, and so on.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:348
verses.text: Then,  I will bless the Lord at all times, and so on.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:349
verses.text: Then,  I will extol Thee, my God, O King, and so on.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:350
verses.text: Then,  O praise the Lord, all ye nations, and so on.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:351
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:352
verses.text: Sir, pronounce the blessing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:353
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:354
verses.text: The Lord will bless us, and keep us without condemnation for the communion of His pure gifts, now and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:355
verses.text: And when they have filled, the Deacon says:—  Sir, pronounce the blessing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:356
verses.text: The Priest says:—  The Lord will bless us, and make us worthy with the pure touchings of our fingers to take the live coal, and place it upon the mouths of the faithful for the purification and renewal of their souls and bodies, now and always.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:357
verses.text: Then,  O taste and see that the Lord is good; who is parted and not divided; distributed to the faithful and not expended; for the remission of sins, and the life everlasting; now and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:358
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:359
verses.text: In the peace of Christ, let us sing:  The Singers.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:360
verses.text: O taste and see that the Lord is good.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:361
verses.text: The Priest says the prayer before the communion.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:362
verses.text: O Lord our God, the heavenly bread, the life of the universe, I have sinned against Heaven, and before Thee, and am not worthy to partake of Thy pure mysteries; but as a merciful God, make me worthy by Thy grace, without condemnation to partake of Thy holy body and precious blood, for the remission of sins, and life everlasting.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:363
verses.text: XLIII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:364
verses.text: Then he distributes to the clergy; and when the deacons take the disks and the chalices for distribution to the people, the Deacon, who takes the first disk, says:—  Sir, pronounce the blessing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:365
verses.text: The Priest replies:—  Glory to God who has sanctified and is sanctifying us all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:366
verses.text: The Deacon says:—  Be Thou exalted, O God, over the heavens, and Thy glory over all the earth, and Thy kingdom endureth to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:367
verses.text: And when the Deacon is about to put it on the side-table the Priest says:—  Blessed be the name of the Lord our God for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:368
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:369
verses.text: In the fear of God, and in faith and love, draw nigh.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:370
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:371
verses.text: Blessed is He that cometh in the name of the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:372
verses.text: And again, when he sets down the disk upon the side-table, he says:—  Sir, pronounce the blessing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:373
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:374
verses.text: Save Thy people, O God, and bless Thine inheritance.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:375
verses.text: The Priest again.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:376
verses.text: Glory to our God, who has sanctified us all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:377
verses.text: And when he has put the chalice back on the holy table, the Priest says:—  Blessed be the name of the Lord to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:378
verses.text: The Deacons and the People say:—  Fill our mouths with Thy praise, O Lord, and fill our lips with joy, that we may sing of Thy glory, of Thy greatness all the day.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:379
verses.text: And again:—  We render thanks to Thee, Christ our God, that Thou hast made us worthy to partake of Thy body and blood, for the remission of sins, and for life everlasting.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:380
verses.text: Do Thou, in Thy goodness and love, keep us, we pray Thee, without condemnation.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:381
verses.text: The prayer of incense at the last entrance.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:382
verses.text: XLIV.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:383
verses.text: We render thanks to Thee, the Saviour and God of all, for all the good things Thou hast given us, and for the participation of Thy holy and pure mysteries, and we offer to Thee this incense, praying: Keep us under the shadow of Thy wings, and count us worthy till our last breath to partake of Thy holy rites for the sanctification of our souls and bodies, for the inheritance of the kingdom of heaven: for Thou, O God, art our sanctification, and we send up praise and thanksgiving to Thee, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:384
verses.text: The Deacon begins in the entrance.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:385
verses.text: Glory to Thee, glory to Thee, glory to Thee, O Christ the King, only-begotten Word of the Father, that Thou hast counted us, Thy sinful and unworthy servants, worthy to enjoy thy pure mysteries for the remission of sins, and for life everlasting: glory to Thee.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:386
verses.text: And when he has made the entrance, the Deacon begins to speak thus:—  XLV.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:387
verses.text: Again and again, and at all times, in peace, let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:388
verses.text: That the participation of His Holy rites may be to us for the turning away from every wicked thing, for our support on the journey to life everlasting, for the communion and gift of the Holy Spirit;  Let us pray.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:389
verses.text: The Priest prays.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:390
verses.text: Commemorating our all-holy, pure, most glorious, blessed Lady, the God-Mother and Ever-Virgin Mary, and all the saints that have been well-pleasing to Thee since the world began, let us devote ourselves, and one another, and our whole life, to Christ our God:  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:391
verses.text: To Thee, O Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:392
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:393
verses.text: XLVI.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:394
verses.text: O God, who through Thy great and unspeakable love didst condescend to the weakness of Thy servants, and hast counted us worthy to partake of this heavenly table, condemn not us sinners for the participation of Thy pure mysteries; but keep us, O good One, in the sanctification of Thy Holy Spirit, that being made holy, we may find part and inheritance with all Thy saints that have been well-pleasing to Thee since the world began, in the light of Thy countenance, through the mercy of Thy only-begotten Son, our Lord and God and Saviour Jesus Christ, with whom Thou art blessed, together with Thy all-holy, and good, and quickening Spirit: for blessed and glorified is Thy all-precious and glorious name, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:395
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:396
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:397
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:398
verses.text: Peace be to all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:399
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:400
verses.text: And to thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:401
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:402
verses.text: XLVII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:403
verses.text: Let us bow our heads to the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:404
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:405
verses.text: O God, great and marvellous, look upon Thy servants, for we have bowed our heads to Thee.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:406
verses.text: Stretch forth Thy hand, strong and full of blessings, and bless Thy people.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:407
verses.text: Keep Thine inheritance, that always and at all times we may glorify Thee, our only living and true God, the holy and consubstantial Trinity, Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, now and ever, and to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:408
verses.text: (Aloud.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:409
verses.text: )  For unto Thee is becoming and is due praise from us all, and honour, and adoration, and thanksgiving, Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, now and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:410
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:411
verses.text: XLVIII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:412
verses.text: In the peace of Christ let us sing:  And again he says:—  In the peace of Christ let us go on:  The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:413
verses.text: In the name of the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:414
verses.text: Sir, pronounce the blessing.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:415
verses.text: Dismission prayer, spoken by the Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:416
verses.text: Going on from glory to glory, we praise Thee, the Saviour of our souls.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:417
verses.text: Glory to Father, and Son, and Holy Spirit now and ever, and to all eternity.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:418
verses.text: We praise Thee, the Saviour of our souls.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:419
verses.text: The Priest says a prayer from the altar to the sacristy.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:420
verses.text: XLIX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:421
verses.text: Going on from strength to strength, and having fulfilled all the divine service in Thy temple, even now we beseech Thee, O Lord our God, make us worthy of perfect loving-kindness; make straight our path: root us in Thy fear, and make us worthy of the heavenly kingdom, in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom Thou art blessed, together with Thy all-holy, and good, and quickening Spirit, now and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:422
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:423
verses.text: L.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:424
verses.text: Again and again, and at all times, in peace let us beseech the Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:425
verses.text: Prayer said in the sacristy after the dismissal.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:426
verses.text: Thou hast given unto us, O Lord, sanctification in the communion of the all-holy body and precious blood of Thy only-begotten Son, our Lord Jesus Christ; give unto us also the grace of Thy good Spirit, and keep us blameless in the faith, lead us unto perfect adoption and redemption, and to the coming joys of eternity; for Thou art our sanctification and light, O God, and Thy only-begotten Son, and Thy all-holy Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:427
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:428
verses.text: In the peace of Christ let us keep watch.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:429
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:430
verses.text: Blessed is God, who blesseth and sanctifieth through the communion of the holy, and quickening, and pure mysteries, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:431
verses.text: Then the prayer of propitiation.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:432
verses.text: O Lord Jesus Christ, Son of the living God, Lamb and Shepherd, who takest away the sin of the world, who didst freely forgive their debt to the two debtors, and gavest remission of her sins to the woman that was a sinner, who gavest healing to the paralytic, with the remission of his sins; forgive, remit, pardon, O God, our offences, voluntary and involuntary, in knowledge and in ignorance, by transgression and by disobedience, which Thy all-holy Spirit knows better than Thy servants do:  And if men, carnal and dwelling in this world, have in aught erred from Thy commandments, either moved by the devil, whether in word or in deed, or if they have come under a curse, or by reason of some special vow, I entreat and beseech Thy unspeakable loving-kindness, that they may be set free from their word, and released from the oath and the special vow, according to Thy goodness.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 2:433
verses.text: Verily, O Sovereign Lord, hear my supplication on behalf of Thy servants, and do Thou pass by all their errors, remembering them no more; forgive them every transgression, voluntary and involuntary; deliver them from everlasting punishment: for Thou art He that hast commanded us, saying, Whatsoever things ye bind upon earth, shall be bound in heaven; and whatsoever things ye loose upon earth, shall be loosed in heaven: for, thou art our God, a God able to pity, and to save and to forgive sins; and glory is due unto Thee, with the eternal Father, and the quickening Spirit, now and ever, and to all eternity, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:1
verses.text: The Divine Liturgy of the Holy Apostle and Evangelist Mark, The Disciple of the Holy Peter.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:2
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:3
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:4
verses.text: Peace be to all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:5
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:6
verses.text: And to thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:7
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:8
verses.text: Pray.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:9
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:10
verses.text: Lord, have mercy; Lord, have mercy; Lord, have mercy.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:11
verses.text: The Priest prays secretly:  We give Thee thanks, yea, more than thanks, O Lord our God, the Father of our Lord and God and Saviour Jesus Christ, for all Thy goodness at all times and in all places, because Thou hast shielded, rescued, helped, and guided us all the days of our lives, and brought us unto this hour, permitting us again to stand before Thee in Thy holy place, that we may implore forgiveness of our sins and propitiation to all Thy people.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:12
verses.text: We pray and beseech Thee, merciful God, to grant in Thy goodness that we may spend this holy day and all the time of our lives without sin, in fulness of joy, health, safety, holiness, and reverence of Thee.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:13
verses.text: But all envy, all fear, all temptation, all the influence of Satan, all the snares of wicked men, do Thou, O Lord, drive away from us, and from Thy Holy Catholic and Apostolic Church.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:14
verses.text: Bestow upon us, O Lord, what is good and meet.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:15
verses.text: Whatever sin we commit in thought, word, or deed, do Thou in Thy goodness and mercy be pleased to pardon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:16
verses.text: Leave us not, O Lord, while we hope in Thee; nor lead us into temptation, but deliver us from the evil one and from his works, through the grace, mercy, and love of Thine only-begotten Son.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:17
verses.text: (In a loud voice.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:18
verses.text: )  Through whom and with whom be glory and power to Thee, in Thy most holy, good, and life-giving Spirit, now, henceforth, and for evermore.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:19
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:20
verses.text: Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:21
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:22
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:23
verses.text: Peace be to all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:24
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:25
verses.text: And to thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:26
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:27
verses.text: Pray for the king.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:28
verses.text: The People.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:29
verses.text: Lord, have mercy; Lord, have mercy; Lord, have mercy.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:30
verses.text: The Priest prays.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 3:31
