verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:11
verses.text: And they respond:—  Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:12
verses.text: And he unites the two parts, the one with the other, saying:—  Divided, sanctified, completed, perfected, united, and commingled have been these renowned, holy, life-giving, and divine mysteries, the one with the other, in the adorable and glorious name of Thy glorious Trinity, O Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, that they may be to us, O Lord, for the propitiation of our offences and the forgiveness of our sins; also for the grand hope of a resurrection from the dead, and of a new life in the kingdom of the heavens, for us and for the Holy Church of Christ our Lord, here and in every place whatsoever, now and always, and for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:13
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:14
verses.text: In the meantime he signs the host with his right thumb in the form of a cross from the lower part to the upper, and from the right to the left, and thus forms a slight fissure in it where it has been dipped in the blood.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:15
verses.text: He puts a part of it into the chalice in the form of a cross: the lower part is placed towards the priest, the upper towards the chalice, so that the place of the fissure looks to the chalice.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:16
verses.text: He bows, and rising, says:—  Glory be to Thee, O Lord Jesus Christ, who hast made me, unworthy though I be, through Thy grace, a minister and mediator of Thy renowed, holy, life-giving, and divine mysteries: through the grace of Thy mercy, make me worthy of the pardon of my offences and the forgiveness of my sins.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:17
verses.text: He signs himself with the sign of the cross an his forehead, and does the same to those standing round him.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:18
verses.text: The Deacons approach, and he signs each one of them on the forehead, saying:—  Christ accept thy ministry: Christ cause thy face to shine: Christ save thy life: Christ make thy youth to grow.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:19
verses.text: And they respond:—  Christ accept thy oblation.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:20
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:21
verses.text: All return to their own place; and the Priest, after bowing, rises and says, in the tone of the Gospel:—  The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God the Father, and the communion of the Holy Ghost, be with us all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:22
verses.text: The Priest signs himself, and lifts up his hand over his head, so that it should be in the air, and the people be partakers in the singing:—  The Deacon says:—  We all with fear, etc.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:23
verses.text: And at these words:—  He hath given to us His mysteries:  The Priest begins to break the body, and says:—  Be merciful, O Lord, through Thy clemency to the sins and follies of Thy servants, and sanctify our lips through Thy grace, that they may give the fruits of glory and praise to Thy divinity, with all Thy saints in Thy kingdom.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:24
verses.text: And, raising his voice, he says:—  And make us worthy, O Lord our God, to stand before Thee continually without stain, with pure heart, with open countenance, and with the confidence which is from Thee, mercifully granted to us: and let us all with one accord invoke Thee, and say thus: Our Father, etc.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:25
verses.text: The People say:—  Our Father, etc.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:26
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:27
verses.text: O Lord God Almighty, O Lord and our good God, who art full of mercy, we beg Thee, O Lord our God, and beseech the clemency of Thy goodness; lead us not into temptation, but deliver and save us from the evil one and his hosts; because Thine is the kingdom, the power, the strength, the might, and the dominion in heaven and on earth, now and always.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:28
verses.text: He signs himself, and they respond:—  Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:29
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:30
verses.text: And he proceeds:—  Peace be with you.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:31
verses.text: They respond:—  With thee and with thy spirit.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:32
verses.text: He proceeds:—  It is becoming that the holy things should be to the holy in perfection.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:33
verses.text: And they say:—  One holy Father: one holy Son: one Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:34
verses.text: Glory be to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Ghost, for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:35
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:36
verses.text: Praise ye.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:37
verses.text: And they say the responsory.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:38
verses.text: And when the Deacon comes to carry the chalice, he says:—  Let us pray for peace with us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:39
verses.text: The Priest says:—  The grace of the Holy Ghost be with thee, with us, and with those who receive Him.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:40
verses.text: And he gives the chalice to the Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:41
verses.text: The Deacon says:—  Bless, O Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:42
verses.text: The Priest.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:43
verses.text: The gift of the grace of our Life-giver and Lord Jesus Christ be completed, in mercies, with all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:44
verses.text: And he signs the people with the cross.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:45
verses.text: In the meantime the responsories are said.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:46
verses.text: Brethren, receive the body of the Son, cries the Church, and drink ye His chalice with faith in the house of His kingdom.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:47
verses.text: On feast-days.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:48
verses.text: Strengthen, O Lord, etc.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:49
verses.text: On the Lord's day.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:50
verses.text: O Lord Jesus Christ, etc.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:51
verses.text: Daily.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:52
verses.text: The mysteries which we have received, etc.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:53
verses.text: The responsories being ended, the Deacon says:—  All therefore, etc.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:54
verses.text: And they respond:—  Glory be to Himself on account of His ineffable gift.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:55
verses.text: The Deacon.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:56
verses.text: Let us pray for peace with us.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:57
verses.text: The Priest at the middle of the altar says this prayer:—  XX.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:58
verses.text: It is meet, O Lord, just and right in all days, times, and hours, to thank, adore, and praise the awful name of Thy majesty, because Thou hast through Thy grace, O Lord, made us, mortal men possessing a frail nature, worthy to sanctify Thy name with the heavenly beings, and to become partakers of the mysteries of Thy gift, and to be delighted with the sweetness of Thy oracles.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:59
verses.text: And voices of glory and thanksgiving we ever offer up to Thy sublime divinity, O Lord.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:60
verses.text: Another.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:61
verses.text: Christ, our God, Lord, King, Saviour, and Life-giver, through His grace has made us worthy to receive His body and His precious and all-sanctifying blood.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:62
verses.text: May He grant unto us that we may be pleasing unto Him in our words, works, thoughts, and deeds, so that that pledge which we have received may be to us for the pardon of our offences, the forgiveness of our sins, and the grand hope of a resurrection from the dead, and a new and true life in the kingdom of the heavens, with all who have been pleasing before Him, through His grace and His mercies for ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:63
verses.text: On ordinary days.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:64
verses.text: Praise, O Lord, honour, blessing, and thanksgiving we ought to ascribe to Thy glorious Trinity for the gift of Thy holy mysteries, which Thou hast given to us for the propitiation of our offences, O Lord of all.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:65
verses.text: Another.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:66
verses.text: Blessed be Thy adorable honour, from Thy glorious place, O Christ, the propitiator of our offences and our sins, and who takest away our follies through Thy renowned, holy, life-giving, and divine mysteries.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:67
verses.text: Christ the hope of our nature always and for ever, Amen.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:68
verses.text: Obsignation or final benediction.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:69
verses.text: May our Lord Jesus Christ, to whom we have ministered, and whom we have seen and honoured in His renowned, holy, life-giving, and divine mysteries, Himself render us worthy of the splendid glory of His kingdom, and of gladness with His holy angels, and for confidence before Him, that we may stand at His right hand.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:70
verses.text: And on our entire congregation may His mercies and compassion be continually poured out, now and always, and ever.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:71
verses.text: On the Lord's day and on feast-days.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 7:72
verses.text: May He Himself who blessed us with all spiritual blessings in the heavens, through Jesus Christ our Lord, and prepared us for His kingdom, and called us to the desirable good things which neither cease nor perish, as He promised to us in His life-giving Gospel, and said to the blessed congregation of His disciples—Verily, verily I say unto you, that every one who eateth my body and drinketh my blood, abideth in me, and I in him, and I will raise him up at the last day; and he cometh not to judgment, but I will make him pass from death to eternal life:  May He Himself now bless this congregation, and maintain our position, and render glorious our people who have come and rejoiced in receiving His renowned, holy, life-giving, and divine mysteries; and may ye be sealed and guarded by the holy sign of the Lord's cross from all evils, secret and open, now and always.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:37
verses.text: Yet, in an otherwise (generally) useful manual of liturgies, an attempt is made to give it this meaning; and the preceding prayer of "Intense Adoration," addressed to the Great High Priest in the heavens, is debased to eke out the weak idea.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:38
verses.text: Nothing could be more averse to the primitive principle of worship; but it is sufficient to note the fact that the "elevation of the host" revolutionized the eucharistic worship of the West as soon as it was established.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:39

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:40

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:41
verses.text: we possess, are yet liturgies for communicating the faithful, in their turns, one and all; and, so far, they are true to the Scriptures and the precepts of Christ and His Apostles.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:42
verses.text: But well does the pious Hirscher exclaim, with reference to the Mass, as he was obliged to celebrate it in his own gorgeous cathedral at Freiburg in the Breisgau: "What would an Apostle think we were doing, should he enter during our ceremonies?" Also, "I know all that can be said in their favour.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:44

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:47

verses.text: In Germany a passing stranger often sees the pious peasantry at Mass, singing with all their hearts their beautiful German hymns.

verses.text: They are not attending to the Mass, but consoling themselves by spiritual songs, while it goes on without their assistance.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:52
verses.text: The bell rings: they adore the host, but that is all their relation to the worship of the Christian liturgies.

verses.name: Early Liturgies 8:53
verses.text: Hirscher loved their hymns, but bewailed the utter loss of their liturgic communion, once common to the faithful.
